Award.AwardTitle: Manufacturing of Hydrocarbon Fuels from Sunlight, Carbon Dioxide and Water with Metal Nanostructures: Mechanistic Investigations to Improve Performance

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to study the fundamental mechanisms of a recently discovered, highly efficient artificial photosynthesis process utilizing cobalt or iron nanostructures to directly convert carbon dioxide and water into hydrocarbon fuels with solar energy in a simple reaction chamber. The project will address fundamental questions encountered in preliminary research: What is the mechanism of photosynthesis on nanostructured metal surfaces? How does the morphology of the femtosecond laser nano/micro-machined surface and the presence of a three-phase (gas/liquid/solid) interface affect the photosynthesis rate? Answers to these questions will be obtained by studying key aspects of the artificial photosynthesis process such as (a) the surface plasmon optical absorption for light harvesting; (b) the rates of photodissociation and hydrocarbon synthesis; and (c) the lifetime/durability of the metal nanostructures for long-term use. Based on the knowledge acquired through this research, a cost-effective photosynthesis manufacturing process on a large scale can be found to meet global energy needs.

Results from the proposed research will enable scientists to overcome key existing barriers to large-scale applications of the artificial photosynthesis technology. Efficient artificial photosynthesis would reduce the global energy problem, decrease the dependence of the United States on foreign imports and fossil fuels, and address environmental concerns such as the high carbon dioxide concentration in the atmosphere. Information on the properties of the metal nanostructures will also be of value to other fields where nanostructures and photo-physics/chemistry/biology are widely used, such as medicine, environment, chemical production, military, and security. The proposed method is also potentially applicable to fertilizer production with sunlight to greatly impact agriculture. The proposed work will contribute to nurturing multidisciplinary scientists and engineers through research-based education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this award was to study the fundamental mechanism of an artificial photosynthesis process that utilizes cobalt nanostructures to directly convert carbon dioxide and water into hydrocarbon fuels with solar energy in a simple reaction chamber. The project has addressed two fundamental questions: 1) “What is the mechanism of photosynthesis on nanostructured metal surfaces?” and 2) “How does the morphology of the femtosecond laser nano/micro-machined surface and the presence of a three-phase (gas/liquid/solid) interface affect the photosynthesis rate?”.

Metal nanostructures enhance incident light intensity around the tips of the nanostructures through plasmonic excitations. The photons are harvested around the cobalt tips through this enhancement. Due to the broad solar spectrum, the overall enhancement has been calculated to be more than a factor of ten.  The unique feature of the photosynthesis process is that sunlight is focused onto nano-scale tips fabricated on the surface of the Co/CoO photocatalyst, facilitating rapid surface reactions. The high intensity light at the tips of cobalt nanostructures either excites electrons from the valence band and defect states in the CoO layer to its conduction band, or generates hot-electrons in the cobalt and cause them to penetrate into the CoO conduction band. Electrons with energies above the conduction band bottom in CoO move to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) state of the adsorbed CO2 and dissociate the CO2 molecules. 

The results show that the synthesis of hydrocarbons from the disassociated carbon dioxide and water molecules happens on the CoO surfaces, and the synthesized hydrocarbon molecules that have left the surface cannot return to the surface to grow larger. The plasmonic effect leads to more solar energy being allocated to locations with sharper morphology. Higher density of the dissociated CO2 reacting with dissociated H2O molecules around the sharper morphology favors the formation of larger hydrocarbon molecules.  The results suggest that the control of a three-phase (gas/liquid/solid) interface may increase the photosynthesis rate as well as the lifetime of the cobalt catalyst for the hydrocarbon formation. 

Efficient artificial photosynthesis would reduce the global energy problem, decrease the dependence of the United States on foreign imports and fossil fuels, and address environmental concerns such as high carbon dioxide concentration in the atmosphere. Information on the properties of metal nanostructures will also be of value to other fields where nanostructures and photo-physics/chemistry/biology are widely used, for example, to the fields of medicine, environment, chemical production, military, and security.  The research in this project has also contributed to nurturing multidisciplinary scientists and engineers through research-based education. A total of six graduate students (including one female student) participated in and contributed to this project, three of them having obtained their Ph. D. degrees. Five undergraduate students (including one female student) were involved in the research and were trained on various aspects of this project.  The PI also introduced the knowledge obtained in this project to his classes at University of Massachusetts, Lowell and to his seminars given at other institutions. The research results have led to three papers to be polished in scientific journals.  The technology in this project has resulted in gaining patents to attract investors for the commercialization.  Based on the technology in this project, a spinoff (solargasoline.com) from the PI's lab has been launched.
